title: Justice: What's the Right Thing to Do?
description: Michael Sandel's 'Justice: What's the Right Thing to Do?' examines various theories of justice by scrutinising moral dilemmas in society. He explores utilitarianism, libertarianism, and the ethics of virtue, presenting real-life scenarios to provoke critical thinking about justice. Sandel challenges students to analyse complex ethical questions, debating issues like affirmative action, wealth distribution, and individual rights. He questions whether fairness and moral reasoning should guide societal decisions and advocates for a deeper understanding of justice beyond abstract principles, urging individuals to engage in meaningful discourse on moral values in the pursuit of a just society.

title: What is History?
description: Edward Hallett Carr, a prominent British historian and international relations theorist. He argues that history is not an objective record of facts but rather an interpretation of events influenced by the historian's perspective, social context, and biases. Carr's book explores the subjective nature of historical interpretation and emphasizes the role of the historian in shaping the narrative of the past. He delves into the idea that historical facts are not merely discovered but are selected and interpreted based on the historian's worldview and the prevailing societal norms and values.

title: What is Art?
description: Leo Tolstoy's 'What is Art?' explores the essence of genuine art as a means of transferring sincere emotions universally. Art, he contends, must transcend cultural barriers and communicate moral truths while evoking shared feelings. He distinguishes between true art, which connects people by expressing honest emotions and universal values, and false art that serves the interests of a privileged class. Tolstoy emphasizes art's societal role, advocating for its moral and educative function. He challenges conventional views, asserting that art should inspire empathy, understanding, and moral growth, prompting introspection into the purpose of art beyond aesthetics, beauty, and elite interests.

title: The theory of the leisure class
description: Thorstein Veblen's 'The Theory of the Leisure Class' scrutinises the emerging industrial society of the late 19th century, examining the conspicuous consumption and social stratification prevalent among the wealthy. Veblen coined the term 'conspicuous consumption' to describe the wasteful spending of the elite to display social status rather than meet genuine needs. He analyses the role of the leisure class, emphasising their unproductive lifestyle and the pursuit of social esteem through lavish displays. Veblen's work highlights the clash between traditional values and the evolving economic system, critiquing the influence of conspicuous consumption on societal values, economic development, and the perpetuation of class divisions.

title: The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money
description: John Maynard Keynes' 'The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money' revolutionised economics in the 20th century. Published in 1936, it challenged classical economic thought prevailing at the time. Keynes argued that during economic downturns, markets might not naturally self-correct due to insufficient demand, leading to unemployment. He proposed government intervention through fiscal and monetary policies to manage aggregate demand, stimulating economic activity and reducing unemployment. Keynes emphasized the importance of effective demand in driving economic output and advocated for active government involvement to maintain employment levels. His ideas significantly influenced economic policy, shaping modern macroeconomic theories and policies worldwide.

title: The open society and its enemies
description: Karl Popper's 'The Open Society and Its Enemies' critically examines the philosophical roots of totalitarian ideologies, primarily focusing on Plato, Hegel, and Marx. Published in 1945, Popper defends liberal democracy and advocates for an open society that encourages critical thinking, individual freedoms, and tolerance. He criticises historicism and the belief in predetermined historical laws, arguing for a society that fosters pluralism and allows for the correction of its own errors. Popper asserts that an open society, founded on principles of democracy and critical discourse, stands as the best defence against authoritarianism and dogmatic ideologies that threaten personal liberties and social progress.

title: Progress & Poverty
description: 'Progress and Poverty,' published in 1879, critiques the social issues arising from unequal distribution of wealth in rapidly growing industrial societies. George examines the paradox of progress leading to poverty despite technological advancements. He proposes a single tax on land, advocating for the communal ownership of land value to prevent monopolies and speculation, aiming to alleviate poverty and achieve economic justice. George argues that by taxing land value instead of individual labor or capital, society can reduce inequality, promote economic progress, and create a fairer system benefiting all members of society.

title: Peddling Prosperity
description: Paul Krugman's 'Peddling Prosperity' (1994) critiques economic policies prevalent in the late 20th century. He challenges the rise of supply-side economics and advocates for a return to Keynesian policies. Krugman scrutinises the flawed economic theories and policies advocated by politicians and academics, highlighting their limitations and consequences on societal welfare. He advocates for a more pragmatic approach, focusing on demand-side policies to address economic issues, debunking myths propagated by conservative economic ideologies. Krugman's work calls for a reassessment of economic strategies, advocating for more effective and evidence-based policies to achieve sustainable growth and prosperity.

title: The Grand Scribe's Records, The Memoirs of China
description: Sima Qian's 'The Grand Scribe's Records' (compiled around 94 BC) is a monumental work detailing China's history from ancient times to his era. Written during the Han dynasty, it chronicles rulers, events, and societal developments, blending historical facts with legends and myths. Qian's narrative style illuminates key figures like Confucius, offering insights into Chinese philosophy, culture, and governance. It serves as a primary historical source, preserving invaluable records of ancient China. Qian's dedication to accuracy and comprehensive documentation laid the groundwork for historical writing in China, providing a rich tapestry of the country's past and influencing subsequent historical works worldwide.

title: Nanjung Ilgi: War Diary
description: Admiral Yi Sun-sin's 'Nanjung Ilgi: War Diary' is a personal account chronicling his naval battles during the Imjin War (1592-1598). Composed between 1592 and 1598, the diary details Yi's strategies, victories, and challenges defending Korea against Japanese invasions. It offers insights into naval tactics, wartime decisions, and the challenges faced by the Korean fleet. Yi's meticulous records illuminate his leadership, resilience, and unwavering commitment to protecting his country. The diary, a testament to his strategic brilliance and dedication, stands as a crucial historical document, providing a firsthand account of significant naval battles and offering lessons in leadership and military strategy.

title: Tao Te Ching
description: ''Tao Te Ching'' is an ancient Chinese philosophical text exploring the concept of Tao (The Way). Composed around the 6th century BCE, it comprises 81 short poetic verses reflecting on harmony, nature, and the art of governing. The text emphasises the paradoxical nature of the Tao, advocating for simplicity, spontaneity, and the acceptance of natural rhythms. Laozi explores the balance between action and non-action (wu-wei), urging individuals to embrace humility and detachment from desires. With its profound wisdom and enigmatic verses, the ''Tao Te Ching'' remains a cornerstone of Taoist philosophy, offering insights into a harmonious life guided by the Tao.

title: On Liberty
description: ''On Liberty'' (1859) advocates for individual freedom against societal and governmental constraints. Mill argues that personal liberty is paramount unless it causes harm to others, advocating for maximal personal autonomy and minimal state intervention. He champions free expression, diversity of opinion, and the value of dissent in fostering societal progress. Mill defends the 'harm principle,' asserting that the only justification for restricting individual freedom is to prevent harm to others. His work remains influential, advocating for the importance of individual liberties, the protection of minority voices, and the constraints required for a just and free society.

title: The Communist Manifesto
description: ''The Communist Manifesto'' (1848) is a revolutionary socio-political pamphlet advocating for the overthrow of capitalist systems. It critiques class struggles and capitalist exploitation, envisioning a classless society where wealth and resources are collectively owned. The manifesto outlines historical conflicts between the bourgeoisie and proletariat, predicting the eventual downfall of capitalism due to its internal contradictions. Marx and Engels propose the establishment of a socialist society where workers control the means of production. Their seminal work remains influential, shaping discussions on economic inequality, capitalism's limitations, and the quest for a more equitable society worldwide.

title: The Social Contract
description: ''The Social Contract'' (1762) deliberates on the relationship between individuals and society. He explores the concept of a social contract, suggesting that legitimate political authority arises from a collectively agreed-upon contract among citizens. Rousseau contends that people surrender some individual freedoms for the common good, forming a sovereign body (the general will) that represents the collective interests of the community. He advocates for direct democracy and stresses the importance of citizens' participation in the political process. Rousseau's ideas laid the groundwork for modern democratic principles, influencing discussions on governance, citizenship, and the balance between individual rights and societal obligations

title: The prince
description: ''The Prince'' (1532) is a key political treatise exploring effective leadership and governance. Machiavelli provides pragmatic guidance to rulers, stressing the need for a realistic grasp of politics, power, and leadership. He advises on tactics for acquiring, preserving, and fortifying political authority, often prioritising stability over moral considerations. Machiavelli challenges traditional ethical ideals in politics, advocating for the strategic use of guile, force, and manipulation for political success. His insights into the practicalities of governance and the nexus between leadership and power continue to stimulate debates on statecraft and political philosophy.

title: Apology, Crito, and Phaedo of Socrates
description: ''Apology'' details Socrates' courtroom defense against charges of impiety and corruption, illustrating his dedication to truth and unwavering philosophical beliefs. In ''Crito,'' Socrates deliberates escape from prison but chooses to abide by the law's consequences, honouring moral principles. Lastly, ''Phaedo'' captures Socrates' final moments before his execution, discussing the immortality of the soul and philosophical contemplations on death. Plato's dialogues immortalise Socrates' philosophy, portraying his steadfast commitment to truth, virtue, and the pursuit of wisdom amidst challenging circumstances.

title: Nicomachean Ethics
description: ''Nicomachean Ethics'' is a profound philosophical treatise exploring ethics and human virtue. Penned around 350 BC, it delves into the nature of happiness (eudaimonia) and the moral virtues crucial for a fulfilling life. Aristotle defines virtue as a balance between extremes (the doctrine of the mean) and stresses the nurturing of virtues through habitual practice. He examines moral character, the significance of friendships, and the role of ethical behaviour in achieving a flourishing life. The text delves into the intricacies of ethical decision-making, advocating the pursuit of excellence and the development of virtuous habits to attain a life of genuine fulfilment and moral goodness.

title: Walk-in the Classic Law books
description: Through core legal concepts like freedom, equality, rule of law, social contract, peace, protection of minorities, civil disobedience, right to resist, principle of legality, and judicial review, the book reconsiders what law and justice mean in Korean society. Despite dealing with challenging classics, it's structured as lectures, making it accessible even for all group of age readers.

title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running
description: An intimate look at writing, running, and the incredible way they intersect, from the incomparable, bestselling author Haruki Murakami. While simply training for New York City Marathon would be enough for most people, Haruki Murakamis decided to write about it as well. The result is a beautiful memoir about his intertwined obsessions with running and writing, full of vivid memories and insights, including the eureka moment when he decided to become a writer. By turns funny and sobering, playful and philosophical, What I Talk About When I Talk About Running is rich and revelatory, both for fans of this masterful yet guardedly private writer and for the exploding population of athletes who find similar satisfaction in athletic pursuit.

title: Korean History
description: In Korean history book, Author Choi Tae-sung emphasises how history offers crucial insights into the past, shaping our understanding of the present and guiding our future. It imparts lessons from human experiences, fostering critical thinking, informed decision-making, and cultural appreciation. He illustrates how history cultivates identity, empathy, and acts as a compass for navigating contemporary challenges.

title: A bit of Art & Humanities
description: This is an introductory book to the humanities. It offers a broad range of humanities knowledge, including Western Philosophy, Eastern Philosophy, Modern Thought, Western Art History, and History, in an easy and enjoyable manner. The book summarises a total of 42 thoughts from Plato to Jean Baudrillard, providing encounters with various social issues, historical events, diverse examples encountered in real life, and humanities knowledge.

title: Economics, The User's Guide
description: Published in 2014, it navigates through various economic theories, historical contexts, and contemporary issues, offering accessible insights into complex economic concepts. The book elucidates key economic principles, shedding light on capitalism, globalization, inequality, and development. Ha-Joon challenges conventional economic ideas, advocating for a more inclusive and balanced approach. His engaging style and real-world examples facilitate a deeper understanding of economics, empowering readers to critically analyze economic phenomena, fostering a nuanced perspective towards the discipline. Overall, it's an informative and accessible guide for readers from diverse backgrounds.

title: Reversal
description: This book, penned by Ja-chung, delineates the path to financial freedom in seven insightful steps. Embrace your true self, establish a goal, and then enhance your mind daily through reading and writing. Ultimately, position yourself for success, attaining financial freedom may involve setbacks, but these challenges foster growth along the way.

title: The Cafe on the Edge of the World: A Story About the Meaning of Life
description: The inspirational #1 Bestseller by John P. Strelecky. Now translated into forty-two languages and read by more than 6 million readers worldwide. In a small cafe at a location so remote it sits in the middle of the middle of nowhere, John--a man in a hurry--is at a crossroads. Intent only on refueling before moving along on his road trip, he finds sustenance of an entirely different kind. In addition to the specials of the day, the cafe menu lists three questions all diners are encourage to consider. Why are you here? Do you fear death? Are you fulfilled. With this food for thought and the guidance of three people he meets at the cafe, John embarks on a journey of self-discovery that takes him from the executive suites of the advertising world to the surf of Hawaii's coastline. Along the way he discovers a new way to look at life, himself, and just how much you can learn from a green sea turtle.
